Come on. Did you really?

I'm from New Jersey.

I love it.
I love it.
It is my favorite accent.
I went to theater college

Because my mother's from Brooklyn

My point of view versus Tamsen,
the amazing, amazing actress Tamsen.
Carol, who was the original...
Yes.
Miss Hedge.
But the...
And she's amazing.

Yeah.

And I love...
I have an affinity for Northerners.
I love all of the UK obviously.
You are almost English, really.
That's the honest.
You're very long.
I have a affinity.
A lot of people are here a lot,
but I've been here a lot since I was 13.
First time I came over and I fell in love.
And I often say that in a past life,
oops, in a past life,
I was obviously British.

I can't...

I feel like that.
I feel like that.

it was an honor for me that John McCree,
who plays Jamie, the brilliant, brilliant John McCree,
said he was doing a talk recently

That was the biggest...
That was the biggest.
That was great.
I'm going to tell you something, actually.
A friend of mine went recently and they were like,

I recognise all the way through and I was like,
it's Michelle Visage.

That says a lot about them if they didn't know
that was me seeing...
They're obviously very drunk.
But I'm playing...
She's a teacher and in my head, she grew up
in the council houses and she got out and she went to uni
and she got a master's degree and she's a teacher
and she ended up back in the council houses teaching herself.
Oh, right.
She's a bit...
A biter and...
Angry, can't hold a man.
Yeah.
So it's not that...
In my eyes, the way I'm playing it is different
to the way Tamsen played it.
In my eyes, she loves Jamie.
She loves that he's gay.
She doesn't have a problem with that.
She has a problem with him not listening to her.
She's trying to say, listen, I've done this.
It's not going to work out the way you think it is.
Save it.
The school is not the time or the place to do this.
Stop it and start listening to me.
Yeah.
Yeah.
You're good, but not here.
Right, you little buggers.
Get in touch with me at the hashtag R1 Drag Queen's Den.
So listen, I've spoken to a lot of people
and a thing that really interests me always
is the motivation for drag.
Why?
Because I think everybody's is very different
of why they get to that point.
You know?
Like, mine was to just go wild
and be a crazy nutbag and...
So do you do drag?
I used to.
What, if you call it drag, I don't know.
I mean, I do...
Drag is relative.
I think so and I think...
Personal.
Exactly.
I totally agree.
It's about your motivation and about your journey to get there.
You know, and I think that people come from all different places.
Do you...
Because in a weird way, you get held
in the same breath as all the drag queens.
You know, what was your route?
I moved to New York City from New Jersey
when I was 17 years old to go to musical theater.
Yeah.
College, uni, you would call it.
Yeah.
And my mother said to me,
we didn't have computers back then because I'm old
and we didn't have cell phones because I'm old.
But she said to me, you need to go out.
The place that we met people were bars and clubs.
And that's how you were discovered in New York City in the 80s
and that's just what it was.
Yeah.
I didn't have an ID and I never drank.
I was never a drinker.
So my mother got me a fake ID
and she sent it to my dorm.
Good mom.
Yeah.
And she said, now you're going to go.
You have no excuses.
I used to go home on the weekends to go to the underage clubs in New Jersey.
She said, you're in New York City now
and you're going to make it happen.
Oh my god.
Go on.
So I just got me a fake ID.
I wore it.
She was amazing.
My mother, rest of these.
I go and I went by myself.
And I dragged.
That is bold.
I know it was.
But my roommate in college said, I'll meet you there.
And she did later on.
But I remember walking in a club called the Underground
that obviously doesn't exist anymore.
But few do.
And I walked down these steps and I was nervous.
I didn't know anybody but I thought, well, I'm going to go dance.
So I go down these steps and this beautiful, beautiful brown skin.
Obviously, Femme, Flemme Boyant Lakeay.
Boy, comes up to me and he said, what's your name?
And I was literally looking around like me?
Yeah.
Because I was obviously New Jersey big frosted hair, baby pink lips,
fake tan.
Yeah.
That was in big New York City.
New to here.
Yeah.
I was full on Essex, a little bull.
Yeah.
But there, it was obviously New Jersey.
And they would call people Bridget Tunnel and that was not good.
I always say that to you.
To you.
Yeah.
Yeah.
So I was Bridget Tunnel full on.
But I owned it.
And I felt really hot.
Yeah.
Like my stomach was out.
The guy at the door was like, I'm going to call you abs.
And I was like, OK.
So I walked into this beautiful boy.
His name is David.
He's no longer with us.
Brought me down the steps.
And he was like, come, come hang out with us.
And I was like, OK.
He literally looked at me in the face and said, you're the most beautiful face.
I have ever seen in my entire life.
And as a 17-year-old girl who grew up feeling ugly,
feeling not wanted, never fit in.
Nobody understood my weirdness.
I was obsessed with Sid Vicious.
Nobody got my punk rock pass.
I finally felt like somebody is getting me.
And then he took me down the steps and brought me to this weird back room.
And it sounds like it's some sex shop.
I swear to it wasn't.
It was a room of like 20 to 30 of the weirdest
craziest, gayest freaks I've ever seen in my life.
And I often say, Dorothy clicked her heels three times and ended up back,
you know, in Kansas.
I clicked my heels three times and ended up on Christopher Street in New York City.
Yeah.
With the community, which is why I get a lot of flack
for calling myself part of the community.
But I've always only known it to be part of the community.
That's where I felt at home.
That's why there have been people along the way
that have used the community to garner them attention
or a better career.
I will never, ever, ever leave the community
because it's always been a home base for me.
Yeah.
Everything, even my days in radio,
where I couldn't really focus on like in music,
in my pop music I could, on the radio,
you can't really focus on just the community.
My nails keep slashing the microphone.
Well, they are serious nails.
Thank you.
I felt like I'm home.
And this is where I was always meant to be.
So drag for me, I grew up on the cotton teats of drag queens.
So I guess there's an identifiable thing there
about feeling like the weirdo or the underdog
or feeling misrepresented.
I think that that is a lot of things that drag queens
have little weird kids.
Jackie, I know that you were a very weird kid.
Yeah.
And you identify with the whole punk thing

Like come out of your shell.
Yeah, absolutely.
So Halloween parties, I would always dress as like
free to Carlo or some sexy space fixer or this or suit you.
Me too.
And all that sort of stuff.
Did you do Dame Bible Cartlin?
I did Dame Bible Cartlin.
And as well.
Yeah.
And you got her kids.
And then I started to sort of like hang out

and saw the kind of drag that they were doing.
And the kind of drag that they were doing was very loose as well.
So it was kind of a...
It's very British.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And very irreverent and like, you know,
which is fabulous.
Even if we don't put together in the most amazing way,
just my...
Still fabulous.
Yeah, but it's the thing that's the confusion
that we should talk upon.
Yeah.
Drag has been around hundreds of years
way before we've lost our eyes.
And it's going to be around way after RuPaul's Drag Race.
Even if we never have another drag television show.
Yeah.
It's going to be around.
It's going to exist.
So because of what you see on RuPaul's Drag Race,
I think that there's a lot of people
who feel that they're not good enough in drag or that.
Right.
But that's not true.
I think just like you're saying,
there's all different angles of drag.
RuPaul's Drag Race as a television show.
We're very specific.
It's what we do.
That's what it's not.
It's a TV show.
Correct.
And it's what we're presenting.
It's not what drag is.
Ru started out as what you're describing.
Ru has always been that.
And Dr. Aginist,
he's from New York Underground.
Yeah.
That's very much our background, actually,
where we come in an R-Drag,
Glogg, Glogg, Glogg, Glogg, Glogg, Glogg, Glogg,
it's all water, it's all water.
You need to see.
Great, babes.
I've always your turn into powder.

regardless of television?
Well, I think Jackie just hit upon it.
I think there's an unfinished edge to British drag,
which makes it quintessentially British.
Yeah.
Which is what I love, you know what I mean?
And I think that we'll see that
on RuPaul's Drag Race UK.
I don't think that we're...
I don't want people to think that we're just going

No, you know.
Right.
And RuPaul's Drag Race has had in the past some,
like, really sort of like, out there characters.
Well, like Tommy Brown and...

But Sharon is polished, though.
Now, she...
She even then, if you watch her season four,
she was polished in her way.
That's what I'm saying.
It's all...
Jinks was a bit...
Jinks was very messy at the beginning.
But it's all...
And I wrote her for it,
but she ended up...
It was a cocoon into a butterfly story.
I love J.
And it's not...
Oh, she's one of my favorite people on the planet.
And it's not that it wasn't good then.
It was good then.
It just...
I knew it could be better.
Yes.
Yeah, yeah.
You know, so why not strive for the best?
How is it going to translate then onto the...
onto the beab?
How...
What are you looking for this different?
It's going to translate beautifully.
Yeah.
Marvelously.
It...
The magic of drag is...
It's like the language of love.
Everybody gets it at this point,
thanks to RuPaul's Drag Race.
And I want, you know,
along with the love comes tons of hate.
Because...
Social media as well.
It's just an angry, angry place.
Yes.
And I wish it wasn't...
Doesn't it just?
Because it brings me back to what I was just saying about...
When I first got involved with the community,
they welcomed me with open arms, no matter.
Yeah.
It didn't matter that I was a cis-heterofemail.
Yeah.
I was just me.
It's not the beauty of our community.
But that's what we're missing now.
Because of the younger generation now,
I'm not just going to blame the kids,
because I love the kids.
I have two kids.
I have a queer daughter,
and a cis-gender,
a heteronormative daughter.
And we all get along famously.
But neither one of them know about hate,
because...
I mean, they know about it,
but not in regards to the community.
So what's missing is the all-encompassing open arms
that was there in the early 80s.
We've got a nurture, I think, regardless.
Because I think if the one thing that we all know,
it's oppression.
And so we've got to actually just be supporting each other.
Jack, have you felt support
or have you felt ostracized by the scene at any point?
I'm not asked.
I feel pretty well supported.
Because you are in the scene, you know?
Yeah.
You have been propping up East London bars for 10 years.
What I see is that...
And...
I've seen you running in heels and jog and a jog strap,
just a jog strap all the way down the kingdom road.
What are my favourite looks, darling?
I love seeing.
Of course, I've seen you.
I've seen you.
I was a bit...
I'm a bit...
Christine like.
I was one of my favourite.
My entry into drag was very that,
because I was like really hedonistic
and yeah, just running around in a jog strap.
But always...
So you're rude, by the way.
Yeah.
That was the worst thing,
jog straps and...
A bit of a shoulder pad.
A shoulder pad.
Yeah, a far...
But I've always tried to sort of like be...
Wild and a bit crazy, a bit hedonistic,
but also try and have a few conversations with people.
Yes.
Before sort of like...
I think now with social media and stuff like that,
there's people are really ready to sort of like...
Because there's power in a comment,
and you can quickly slam someone for something.
But they're not dents, you know?
They're not power in it.
There's not power in it if you don't give it the power.
Well, yeah.
Well, I feel that we're almost...
I see a lot of people making statements,
but not making conversations.
Yeah.
That's the problem.
Yeah.
You know, people just literally saying things for shock value.
Right.
But not really ever wanting the conversation.
You follow it up and it just gets stopped.
Right.
Yeah.
I always said that I had my life before,
Sink the Pink, which is the club that I started,
and it was fucking boring.
Right.
And dull, and I didn't really like myself or know myself,
but through my community, through people,
because I've known Jackie for probably about eight years.
Nine years, nine years.
These are my friends for life.
We support each other, we are their thick and thin.
But I do see it.
It is worrying that...
I feel like everything's accelerated now.
Everything's like a million times faster.
Because of social media.
Yeah.
Yes.
So, what can...
For better or for worse?
What can we do?
What can we do?
Let's change the bloody world.
Well, what you can do is use your platform and be a voice
and constantly say the same thing and drive it home
and drive it home.
Panty Bliss is a great example of that.
Oh, yeah.
I saw her show in Australia recently.
She's just a brilliant...
And I had tears in the front row.
She was powerful.
And funny too.
Amazing and relatable.
Yes, so I'd like to...
Advocate, um, lecturer, drag queen, um, HIV positive.
She does all great things for many...
She practices what she appreciates as well.
And I think that's important for us to do within the community.
But it's going to help the youth stop them in their tracks
and say, stop that.
What you're doing...
Listen, I was around, I'm 50.
I've been around for a long time in this community.
I think I started within the community.
The first time I realized that this was my place was in 1986.
In my senior year of high school, where I stuck up for the one gay boy
that people knew was gay in high school.
And he was being made fun of by the straight boys
who hated me anyway because I was a freak.
So they didn't relate to me and I wasn't, you know.
So I stuck up for him and I realized, oh, I got a rush.
This is what I'm supposed to be doing.
Somebody's telling me to do this.
I didn't know that kid.
We weren't friends because he was very quiet.
But something felt right.
So when I moved to New York and met David,
that's where my journey began.
And that's where I realized these people are people too,
despite who they love, despite who they're with,
despite how they dress, despite what they look like.
And I've gotten a lot of flak over the years for that.
But I also got flak for dating black boys.
And I was always out of the box.
I think we're the same person, Michelle.
I think we probably dated the same people.
We may have money.
We may have.
So the point is, if you believe in something strongly enough,
you're allowed to speak up for it and defend it.
I think especially if you see someone going through hardship,
isn't that being a human?
If you see someone vulnerable, you just want to help.
Of course.
I get a lot of flak from parents at school
who will say to me, why are you such a gay rights supporter
when you're a woman and you should be supporting women's rights?
And I went, I didn't know gay rights was exclusive.
Human rights.
Human rights.
Yeah.
I said, I'm strong, starch feminist as well.
I believe in female rights and women's rights and mothers' rights.
But mothers include trans women.
Mother, you know, there's mothers include gay men.
It's for me, it's about humanity.
So why are you asking me?
Why I do what I do.
Now it's time for Dragotics.
And this week's guest, the slut-dropping beauty,
Jade from Little Mix.
What are you?
What you need?
Chucker in the Priory.
It's Dragotics.
Jade, my darling, thank you so much for joining us on Drag Queen's Den.
I understand that you're on a beach.
Is that correct?
I am, I'm a mamiho.
Well, we've got a few questions for you.
Are you ready to take them?
I am.
Always ready.
All right, so listen and tell us when did your addiction to Drag begin?
Ooh, well, I think my first of experiences, Drag,
was actually when I was really little and made my family before the Benadome,
every year.
For a cheap and cheerful holiday, before I watched the Drag Race.
And even from like a young age, like five years old,
I was just obsessed, like I absolutely loved it.
But it wasn't until I was like 20s really, a few years ago
and I was just sitting at home and being a friend.
I was going through Netflix and we finally found Drag Race.
And the rest is history really.
I mean, I'm just absolutely obsessed.
It's really changed my life.
Do you think it's got a lot to do with your hair,
your hair dresser as well, maybe?
Oh, yes.
And my hair stylist Aaron Carlos, when I moved to London,
he sort of took me under his wing,
took me round London to all the fabulous
day bars, all the drags.
And corrupted you.
And all the drags.
So I've got a lot to listen in as well.
Listen, what do you think makes you connect it to the art of drag?
I just think it's absolutely incredible.
Like it's an art form, you know, how these people sort of transform themselves,
you know, especially when they're just sort of
adversely that they can face with the public eye.
Yeah.
I think it's incredibly brave.
And for me personally, it's made me a bit of a performer.
This sort of idea of, yeah, turning yourself into someone else,
like an old Aurego on stage.
Yeah, I just love it.
I've seen you perform many times, and I've got to be honest.
You are a drag queen.
I am.
You are such a drag queen.
So listen, there's been, we spent lots of time together
surrounded by drag queens, but I want to know what's your most memorable and fabulous story
of drag that sticks out to you?
Oh god, too many.
Well, I've got a top three, so I was pretty bashed in the walk.
All right, lovely.
But we first once probably when I did the power of music video,
and the Triple League girls, great to be in it.
Yes, that was a moment.
And I was absolutely star struck.
We were shooting the music video on LA,
and the director had come and tell me to sort of calm down,
and like make sure I actually got in front of the camera,
and remember it with my music.
You know, nothing.
So I was standing like an Aurego.
I love that.
And they were so lovely to me, and still good friends,
supporting me and Willem, who's having time in LA messages.
Also, when I met RuPaul, that was...
Get out.
When did that happen?
Yeah, I would literally.
For me, like my two idols in life are RuPaul and Jaina Rass,
and I'm just a sort of con for these.
I met, I was willing to buy a doll for $1,000
at the drag conference just to meet RuPaul.
That's kind of a question.
That's right, I was.
Yeah.
But luckily Michelle got us in there to meet up with him,
and he was so lovely.
He's very good at making anyone feel special.
Do you think he knew who you were?
Oh, yeah, he did, which I was also like, featured this about.
He just, he thanked me for what I've been trying to do with my way in there.
And you do?
You do so wonderfully.
And yeah, what I've been doing for the community.
Okay, so listen, finally, everybody needs a drag queen name.
So what would be your drag queen name, Jade?
Oh, well, Willem did name his...
She need a nibble.
Because every time I've gone in, I out,
